newsitem.title: ITALY: Huge pro-Italy march puts Bossi in shade.
newsitem.headline: Huge pro-Italy march puts Bossi in shade.

text.p: At least 150,000 Italians marched for unity on Sunday at a far-right rally held to answer northern separatist Umberto Bossi and his push for "independence".

The size of the peaceful demonstration in Milan dwarfed a series of sparsely-attended rallies held since Friday along the River Po, the route of a symbol-laden "March to the Sea" which Bossi had hoped would draw more than one million followers.

As Bossi headed for the canal city of Venice to proclaim his would-be "republic of Padania" later on Sunday, a mass of marchers sporting the red, white and green of the Italian flag thronged the streets of Milan, the north's largest city.
"Italy is here. It won't be insulted and it won't be divided," Gianfranco Fini, leader of the hard right National Alliance party, told a sea of people packed into a central square.
"Secession and division are an insult to history and an insult to reason," Fini said.

As the crowd waved Italian flags and sang the national anthem, he said Bossi's trek across Italy from the source of the Po to the Adriatic had become a "farce" and urged court action following a call by Bossi for formation of a separatist militia.
Police estimated that more than 150,000 people from all over Italy had joined the demonstration in Milan, the country's financial capital and headquarters of Bossi's Northern League.
Organisers put the turnout at 250,000.

Smaller pro-unity rallies also took place on the Po itself, including at San Benedetto Po, where Greens party supporters flew a string of balloons across the river, and at Piacenza, where one banner read: "Free the North, but from the League".

Bossi, who was planning to lead a flotilla of small boats to Venice on the last leg of his quasi-religious pilgrimage, brushed off the scant show of support for his secessionist drive by accusing the media of lies.
"They can't set the Carabinieri (paramilitary police) on us so they're relying on the press to spread disinformation," Bossi told a small rally near the Po town of Pavia on Sunday.

Bossi has promised a peaceful push for independence for his ill-defined "state", which would encompass the richest regions of Italy, but he said on Saturday that one of "Padania's" first acts would be to recruit volunteer militiamen.
"If force is needed, and it is possible that it will be needed, from Monday the provisional government will take care of that with voluntary recruitment of a national guard," he said.
The implicit threat of violence brought a warning from President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro on Sunday that while Italy would guarantee free speech it would not tolerate illegality.
Bossi's League has built its appeal on deep discontent in the north with high taxes and stifling centralised bureaucracy coupled with disillusionment with mainstream political parties.

It won an unexpected 10.6 percent of votes at last April's general election but failed to wrest the balance of power in parliament, a defeat Bossi's critics say explains his switch to a secessionist from a federalist agenda.
Bossi's challenge to Italian unity has solidified support for federal reform across the spectrum from the centre-left government to the opposition.
"Unity and autonomy must travel together in our country," Prime Minister Romano Prodi said on Sunday. "I'm not interested in Bossi...Federalism is born from concrete facts".
He said Bossi's hopes of a "triumphant march" had fallen flat, a view echoed by ordinary Italians.

"We had more people here for our annual boat race," said Ivo Caramaschi, the boat club chairman in the Po town of Borgoforte, where only about 1,000 people had gathered for one of a string of pro-secession rallies planned by the League for Sunday.
